30eWNa4FAQ3qm0brLeuhmA.text: Tis an ill cook that cannot lick his own fingers - William Shakespeare - Romeo and Juliet - act 4, scene 2Wise words from The Bard, which should be a warning to all cooks to taste, taste, taste as they prepare their worldly delights. A tip which I would commend to the chef at The Swan at The Globe.The Globe Theatre is the defacto home of Shakespeare, a reconstruction of his original London theatre, located on the Southbank. The Swan is fully integrated into the theatre building but does have a separate entrance. The décor was very well put together, dark woods and intricate patterns were combined with plain tables and painted wooden chairs in the bar area. Upstairs, the Brasserie, where we were eating, was a simple design of creams and dark browns, with some interesting flower arrangements scattered about. A large dining table at one end provided the possibility of private dining once the heavy curtains were drawn. The layout was comfortable, and we certainly weren't falling across other diners - not least because there weren't many others; rather surprising for such a prime location. The Swan, as our hostess explained, has a busy sitting before the evening performance at the theatre after which the Brasserie closes in order to re-lay tables. J and myself were invited to take a drink at the bar.The menu is small, providing about 7 dishes per course, and all seem reasonably priced. Large menu selections fill me with dread and suspicion: large menus seldom provide fresh, quality produce.So to the food:J opened with potted shrimp, served in an old fashioned clasp fasten jam jar delicately placed on a folded white napkin. Unsure what to do with the napkin, it was swiftly removed. Slight hints of chilli - but ever so slight. My Scallops, with braised lentils and gremolata (the waitress was unsure how to explain what this was - so we only got as far as it's the sauce that comes with the lentils - it was clear she didn't know!), were well cooked: tender, juicy and sweet. The lentils were still very much al dente, bit too much for my liking. The common thread for both dishes however was blandness. And here I refer to my opening quotation. Dishes were well constructed and presented and arrived full of promise. But the lack of basic seasoning deflated two otherwise good plates of food. Taste, taste, taste.J's main course was Elwy Lamb with spring beans and thyme sauce and a side of classic cauliflower cheese. The cauliflower cheese tantalised with a crunchy cheesy top and cauliflower with a bit of a bite. The faintest bit of nutmeg provided a fleeting aftertaste; the sauce a bit thin. The lamb was nicely pink, just as promised.I had a beautifully baked salmon, still moist, with a topping of crisp skin. The accompanying crushed new potatoes and tomato sauce didn't thrill and let down the fish, but I did eat the lot.Once again the basics of seasoning was missing, the importance of which I can not understate. And if you're going to use tantalizing seasoning like nutmeg, then let's make sure it really incorporates into the dish, rather than being an afterthought.Pudding however was another matter and here the chef really excelled. J had a rhubarb pavlova - poached in a ginger syrup and laid on a chewy meringue filled with vanilla infused cream. I had one of the best sticky toffee puddings I've tasted for a long time - moist, sweet, not drowned in sauce. My only criticism is that it wasn't a big enough portion! Food 3/5 - Season and taste!Service 3/5 - Attentive, but staff lacking in menu knowledgeEnvironment 4/5 - Comfortable, décor Elle Decoration would be proud of says J.

GQZEeFKASvoU-Is1veg9kA.text: Sat by the window on a warm summer's eve my mind drift's, surrounded by wonder my energy begins to stir.Then my friend arrives with two double g+t 's fabulous x

OUBkFpAgjDyn6DKmRciFOg.text: A magnificent place to watch magnificent and tremendous classical plays. The theatre is also structured ver well because of the great shape.

QT2NZIDTECOTuTrlCE0WkA.text: Excellent, atmospheric place, couldn't stand up all through a Shakespeare play, so took own cushions and sat on the bench, lovely!

PWJIMoy6Ni9xE5mRfuBOlQ.text: Worth a visit. You can get tickets for the shows from as little as £5 if you don't mind standing and getting that shakespearian experience.

mY3uZ6qTwPvion2rNm2BUQ.text: Without a doubt my favourite touristy attraction in London. In addition to being a rabid Shakespeare fan, I am simply always impressed by the quality of the performances I see at this venue. The actors are amazing, the sets fantastic and the excitement of the audience palpable. While I could gush for ages about the Shakespeare experience I enjoy so much at the Globe, one small thing that always brightens my time at the theatre is the wonderful staff of volunteers who are so knowledgeable and friendly yet give their time for free. Overall a wonderful place in London.

NRpH2UOTA77vc8SXiTXbWw.text: This is a wonderful theatre on the south bank. If you want to see Shakespeare in its rawest form then you have to come here. I have seen the best Shakespeare of my life here, because of the stage you hear the words and are not blinded by huge sets and costume. This is a place everyone has to visit at lest once.

bQimrrEe8DK1NGU0M6IAZg.text: Brilliant place to go to find out more about Shakespeare. Family friendly place. It helped alot with my study of Shakespeare

oZ075b8I5csbu_nzGCDw7Q.text: This is a world class production theatre with some of the finest theatrical actor is London. the acoustics are aweinspriing and many of the plays that are ruined by Hollywood and polished to perfection in this place of dreams. even to those who do not apreciate the subtlety of Shakespeare will find this to be a great place to visit.

4VWq9Ll5uwuV5cN2USu9bw.text: Fun and different. Love the theatre layout and the dedicated staff. King Lear went on a bit late to catch the end on a weeknight. Some of the foreign groups of teenagers attending were irritating (slap the teacher for bringing them?) and the drinks/bar situation can be poorly organised. I'd still go again though.

HySKC9aHBC_QNs_t4w2lPA.text: If you're going to go to the Globe, I say either get the most expensive seats or standing tickets as the others just aren't worth it. There's no expensive sound carrying equipment and the modest stage props suit the environment perfectly. I had not so good seats when I went but shortly after it started got up and stood for the rest of the show which was far more involving and enjoyable. It's a great environment to enjoy theatre within and something which I'd definitely go to again

s6TsLlTkcSZVZO49VisOHg.text: Shakespeare's Globe is one good experience . I've been there a couple of times a year. Most fun is to go and stand - tickets cost £5. This to me is actually better than to pay for a seat because I felt more involved. It doesn't matter if it rains, such is the level of enjoyment. The acting is always first-class, and one has a feeling that there's a commitment from everyone: players, staff and audience. Quite rightly the Globe has become an item on tourism, but it definitely doesn't feel touristy. Anyone will see one of the very finest things the UK can offer.

gG9Z8hS4mhnhXaElLOR5BQ.text: Is this a theatre that I see before me, the door handle toward my hand? Come, let me visit thee. I knew ye not and yet I see thee still. Art thou not, friendly vision, sensible to feeling as to site? Or art thou but a theatre of the mind, a false creation, proceeding from my tourism-oppressed brain? I see thee yet, in form as palapable, as this one on the brochure.. OK, I'm not Shakespeare, but maybe nor was he, according to some rumours. And this is not the Globe. It's a re-creation, not on the original site, envisioned by film-maker Sam Wanamaker. It looks way too new for my liking, and though it pulls in thousands of punters a day, it has an uneasy Disney feel for me. If you want to see where the Globe really was, head south, turn left under the railway bridge and look for a plaque on the wall. It's now a car park for a block of flats. Says it all really.

Po9u5rm-5xrs4oj6FjqY3A.text: A reproduction of the original theatre. The play I saw (The Tempest) here had multiple characters being played by the same actors. It made the play very difficult to follow. The acoustics are mediocre and it's hard to hear what the actors are saying sometimes. Worth a visit, but it's very touristy. Oddly, the seating area had plenty of empty seats but the staff were very strict about not letting anyone sit there unless they had a ticket for the seating area. Avoid buying a standing ticket--it's miserable.

3C3gCfi8zP49hzBxra4W4w.text: You can see some really great plays here, and they're really good quality as they're professional companies and Shakespeare was an awesome playwright! Recently the sets have been getting more and more extravagant, I recently saw The Merry Wives of Windsor which used a great extension to the stage which evolved throughout the play. I'm sure if Shakespeare could have used it he would have done. Don't go for the seats - get the cheap standing tickets every time, as I said it's cheap and you really do get a better atmosphere out in the elements with other fans!

17uS5XXQZIszQHSRTMc7jw.text: This was a great experience. Although it isn't in exactly the same spot as the original theatre, it has been lovingly and carefully recreated- as shown in the small museum included in the ticket price. Watching performances, you really get a true sense of how it would have been at the time, and why Shakespeare had to put certain stage directions and obvious statements in his plays. I don't think I could cope standing for the whole 3 hour play, but tickets are a lot cheaper and you get the true authentic experience if you do! If you go, take a cushion- you can hire them for a couple of pounds, but the seats are basic wooden benches and not that comfortable when you're sitting for that length of time.

shYaAiICtIqECLN7sCQXog.text: The Globe is a great theatre that has been designed to recreate the original theatre Shakespeare performed at. The tour around the theatre is great and takes you all around including back stage. There is also an interesting exhibit which shows the history of the theatre. The shows themselves are great to watch and as with the original Globe theatre you can buy cheap tickets in the pits, this is a area right in front of the stage, however there are no seats and you will need to stand for the duration of the show, so it is not for people with weak knees! Tickets for the pits are only £5. On the plus side you are very close to the actors. However, if it does rain there is no rood over the pit to protect you!

E0dgfCl-Dre5HZdQgLTLAA.text: 'The Globe' theatre is, by far, one of the best attractions in London. From the historical side to the building, just knowing you are in such an amazing place is a great feeling. The way it has been restored to keep with modern necessities, but still having that great Shakespearian feeling is wonderful. I have been here several times now, and have never had a bad experience. It may be traditional, and you may have to stand up, or sit in uncomfortable stands; but it is more than worth it for the cultural benefits you get, and knowing you have been in one of the most famous theatres in the world.

mwG97JTQspFv4WJZihJodQ.text: Back when the bard was in town, he had his plays at the famous globe theatre. The original was destroyed in a fire caused by an onstage fire during the first performance of Henry VII, this replica was lovingly made in 1996 to give us all a flavour of what it was like. It's a must do pilgrimage for scholars of the famous plays and their many fans, it's an education in itself. You can sit on under cover on a bench seat, cushions are available to be hired to save sensitive bottoms, or you can get down in the cheap seats, standing in the yard, which to me is the place to be, it's like a ye olde moshpit. Take a tour too, and remeber all the while, there aint no nails in it, it's all proper carpentry, you know, put together with skill, amazing.

Nc3GCWUblIvALfF9cqrD6Q.text: A visit at The Globe is an experience that simply cannot be missed.Originally built for the performance of Shakespeare stage plays, the theatre building itself is worth admiring. It is beautifully decorated and made out to look like an original theatre from centuries past.The best time to visit The Globe is during the summer, when the performances take place on the stage and under the open sky. Going to see a show such as this really is a unique experience that gives you just an inkling of how theatre was in the past.It is interesting to visit The Globe, even if you do not go there to watch a performance, as there are brilliant guides to show you around at the theatre and tell you about its use and its most remarkable history.As any good museum, The Shakespeare Globe has a well-equipped souvenir shop where many original items such as badges, mugs and t-shirts - all with shakespearean quotations printed on them, can be purchased.

xdY1nShUKLE_s2XkIhO7LA.text: A wonderful view, great atmosphere, and a killer menu. A must stop if you are visiting the globe, or just looking for a nice spot to meet friends or that special someone.

T2jLQvSwpFs-QqBtlMJvkg.text: The absolute lowlight of our recent trip to London.  We booked a table in the restaurant for after our Globe tour: the food was fine but the service was absolutely atrocious.  We ordered a bottle of wine to share, after the initial pour it was placed in an ice bucket in another part of the room rather than next to our table.  That would have been fine if the staff had refilled glasses as needed: they did not.  When all three of our glasses had been empty for some time, one of the other servers noticed.  I saw him tell our server that we obviously needed attention.  She came over immediately, saying "You needed something?"  Really?  My husband asked her for more wine and I had to remind her that we had an open bottle across the room.  My original choice was not to my liking (again, the food is fine, I had taken a recommendation from the server and found it not to my taste.)  The server properly apologized and offered me something else, which I appreciated and thanked her for. Unfortunately, when she brought it she didn't notice that I had no cutlery with which to eat it and disappeared so quickly that I couldn't ask.  I wound up eating my meal with my daughter's salad fork and my butter knife.  The dessert was  some kind of sorbet of a frankly alarming shade floating in a sugary soup with actual multi colored sprinkles on it.  Not to put too fine a point on it, but I'm an American and even I wouldn't touch it.  At this point I got up and retrieved our wine bottle so we could refill our (again!) empty glasses.  None of the servers who observed this offered assistance.  At the close of the meal someone who I assume was a manger asked how the meal was.  I shared my opinion of the service (as diplomatically as possible but after all, he asked) and  was not given an apology but instead was told it was our server's first day.  I don't mean to be insensitive but isn't it the responsibility of the establishment to put properly trained servers on the roster, especially in a restaurant that advertises (and prices) itself as an upscale dining experience?  I rarely give negative reviews but in this case, save your money and visit the downscale Anchor pub a few steps away.  Still a bit of history and you'll get a decent meal for a decent price.

PTIB21qu1vipxNjkbAIguA.text: My boyfriend and I ate here for lunch after going on a tour of the theatre. We were famished, it looked nice and was close.I loved the cozy ambiance with lots of natural light. It has a great vibe. Our server was both very friendly and competent. I had a beef sandwich with horseradish spread and chips for my main. It was okay. It looked really pretty, but tasted just okay. My main memory of the restaurant comes from the starter. Before I tell you my feelings on it, I had to clarify two things... 1. My boyfriend enjoyed it. 2. I think it might be an acquired taste.The Pork Cracklins with Applesauce was the worst thing I ever ate.Ever.The taste was so strong and so vile that I can still taste it as I think about it.The cracklins made such a big impression, it's unfortunately my big take-away from the restaurant.

HOsW_O1bgBKBDG9acKr3IQ.text: Awesome mushy peas!!!We were to meet some friends here on a recent Sunday Funday while in London.  We arrived early and the place was packed.  We scored 2 seats at the bar and ordered some drinks.  We had about 45 minutes to waste.  I decided to go ahead and order some mushy pea toast.  My husBAND didn't see anything on the menu so he ordered just toast.  OMG...that mushy pea toast has me dreaming of visiting London again!!!  It was topped with feta and was just so good!!!  By the time we were done, the place had cleared out and we were nearly the only ones left.  Given my husband's pickiness and the quietness of the place at this point, we decided to move on.However, I would come back Swan at The Globe anyday...if only for the mushy pea toast!!!

lgKt1qWkB2unnxx_jXh6sQ.text: Maybe this is because i have just returned from living in New York where i'm used to better service, however, this place was appalling!!  i went there yesterday and we ordered food and drinks.  Further because we live about 2 blocks away we had been there 3 times in the last 2 weeks.Anyhow...about 2/3 into my pint i find a bug floating in my beer.  i kindly spoke to the waitress to ask if she could kindly just give me another 1/3 pint to replace the amount left in my glass.  She said she would speak to the manager and returned to say they would be happy to sell me another half pint but would not replace my 1/3 pint for free.  Whats  unbelievable is that where i get a bug in my beer on their premises, their first response is to try and profit on this by selling me more beer.....at this point i refused to argue over £1.30 of beer and asked for the cheque.  However, i told the manager that i find it ridiculous that i should be 100% responsible for any bug infestation on their premises.  further i told them "does that mean that where i chose to frequent their bar in future that i am responsible to carry a fly squatter with me"anyhow i paid their bill including the 12.5% service charge they slapped me with.  the problem with touristy places is they are very happy to put a service charge on your bill without making any effort to earn it....

m3-N-FFnDZmY0vjqd9h_Mg.text: Great food, great service and great view - just great!I'd heard good things about the Swan from friends so took my Dad for dinner to mark the last night of his week in London. Dad is in a wheelchair and although the restaurant is on the second floor, fortunately there is a disabled lift around the corner. I ordered the T-Bone and it was cooked to perfection and really tasty, triple cooked chips were a little disappointing........but my expectations may have been a little high! All in all I'd definitely recommend

JPpk3ARkItvtNQhzgVCcYQ.text: This review is about the bar, NOT the restaurant upstairs. Fantastic river views, ok food, bit pricey but then you are next to the River Thames. Unfortunately the waitress forgot our order, causing a lengthy wait, although the manager did compensate by discounting our bill, which was a nice gesture.Would probably go back again to give it another go.

ah2DP6QTKiZziCf_qUntLg.text: I got a 50% off deal through toptable and went to the Swan for brunch today.  Overlooking the Thames on a gorgeous sunny day with chill out music in the background, heaven! Attentive and friendly service, I had the vegetarian English breakfast which was perfect, delicious and beautifully presented. I loved it so much that I got a gift voucher for a friend - champagne brunch will be on me!

okLCMyKqRql3nHjy_hdNCg.text: Wonderful prix fixe pre-theatre meal, excellent food, great service,  good value, amazing views of river and St. Paul's,  couldn't be more blissful.

zJhOnnTVvIAgynCwoW1YOA.text: This was a five-star restaurant in a five-star location. I was skeptical that the food would be any good given its touristy location. But I read Yelp! reviews and was convinced to give it a try. I was not disappointed. We got a table for two by the window overlooking the Thames and the food was as spectacular as the view. We got the fixed price three-course dinner. I had the lamb entree with a broccoli salad and gooseberry tart. My wife had hake, prawn bisque and peach Melba. Delightful!

zH9pg-RF_n4znXsIQntz9w.text: I walked along the Southern embankment, and the weather got bad, so I decided to wait until rain is over and have lunch. I found this place beside me, and never regretted. Beautiful, spacey and light restaurant. Had a nice salad and a good steak. Was great to have lunch looking at rainy Thames.

1_BZHjbwY-_8RgptCI4xPA.text: No matter how close to the theater or how upscale you think you are, you don't let your guests wait 2 hours for a steak. That's like the ground rule for hospitality, and unfortunately you are not even able to maintain that.

lujDsYGb8dLxHQvwTXO7og.text: Such an awesome place. So good that it made me sign up to Yelp to write this review. Staff so great - super friendly and helpful. Amazing cocktail list. Haven't tried the food yet, but I'll be back.

3cQyEWiKs3x8jz72E9mM7Q.text: I popped in here solely for a drink, so please bear in mind that this does not reflect the food.Initial impression was that the space was nice, and location superb.However, my initial optimism gave way to disappointment as a string of simple things niggled at me:(1) Having sat at the bar I didn't get eye contact, a hello, or anything else besides for 5 minutes.(2) No drinks menu out on the bar - you had to ask for them especially. This wasted a further 5 minutes.(3) I proceeded to order a margarita. Despite assurances in the menu, I was not asked how I'd like it served - on the rocks, straight, salt rim or not. They also missed out on a chance to upsell me to a better brand of tequila.(4) They failed to double-strain the drink, which is standard procedure with any shaken drink of this nature.(5) The drink was completely devoid of any garnish - no lime wheel, twist or anything.(6) Margarita was overly dilute and somewhat unbalanced.It's terribly disappointing - I pass by on a regular basis, and there's a dearth of cocktail bars nearby, so it would have been ideal if this was a good drinking hole. Perhaps it is, if you stick to beer, but their cocktails are nowhere near as good as they should be.

Bqt98MnAO5KfBm86hWdDSw.text: In its first staging at The Globe Theatre, All's Well That Ends Well is brought to life in John Doves production. It tells the story of Helena (Ellie Piercy) who is in love with her Count Bertram (Sam Crane) though he doesn't seem to notice she exists. After curing the King of France (played wonderfully by Sam Cox) she is allowed to marry the man of her choosing and chooses Bertram, much to the delight of his mother, the Countess of Roussillion (played delightfully by Janie Dee). As this is a Shakespeare story, nothing goes to plan and Helena is left feeling rejected and in need of a plan to truly win the heart of the man she loves. Although it is one of Shakespeare's lesser than plays, All's Well That Ends Well is the perfect production for a place like The Globe, with its simple storyline and modest scenery and cast. You really feel as if you are personally witnessing this love story unfold as if you were a member of the household and can't help but feel your heart warmed by an ending, that for once, ends the way you feel every love story should. All's Well That Ends Well is showing at The Globe Theatre until August 21st. itsnosmallthing.weebly.c…

1RK94HOf9WG03ZmwEl1BpA.text: On a stretch of river in our capital city filled with world famous buildings and iconic views, there can only be two sureties; loud, jostling hungry tourists, and overpriced, substandard restaurants to feed them.One of the jewels along the waterside is the Globe Theatre. Only a teenager (started by Sam Wannamaker in 1970, opening after his death in 1997), it fits in perfectly with its older neighbours and has rightly become a real destination along the bank. For the last year or so they've also been blessed with the Swan. A lovely little bar and brasserie  adjoining the theatre 'directed' by ex Ramsay cohort Mark Sargeant, there's a sense of real purpose about the menu. They shout loud and proud about their reliance on foragers, farmers and local markets (they are just up the road from Borough Market after all) and the menu reflects this seasonality. Sadly that season has just passed. On a gorgeous spring night it's a shame that most of the food on offer has a distinctly wintery note. Don't get me wrong, I love the sound of the Cashel Blue macaroni cheese and spiced Elizabethan mutton casserole is just what you'd expect to eat before outdoor Shakespeare, but not when the weather outside is so warm.I went for the one seasonal starter. Trimmed asparagus with hollandaise. Sometimes kitchens have to realise that you don't mess with perfection and that was certainly the case. Cooked for a couple of minutes, lightly drizzled with a zingy sauce, it was heaven. Nicco Polo was slightly less lucky. His scallop and spring onion gratin was average at best, with an excess of herbed breadcrumbs and a strong gratin sauce overwhelming the more delicate scallops.The confit pork belly was a big homely portion. Again, not necessarily suited to a spring night, but I'm a big fan of the pig and won't let a little thing like seasonality get in my way. The large slab came with a sweet honey and dill glazed crackling, sweetly tender fat and a creamy, mustardy celeriac remoulade that set it off perfectly.Finishing off with the summer pudding, I was struck by just how conducive the restaurant was to having a good time. It was so friendly and comfortable with some excellent food, that and the very central location mean I'll certainly be coming back. For a very reasonable price, we had three strong courses, an aperitif and a Chilean Pinot Noir from a tasty little list that struggled to top £40 a bottle. Looking out at the tourists crossing the Millennium Bridge as the light gradually faded behind St Paul's dome we wondered how many of them would look up and check out the Swan, or given the sad state of occupancy would they all end up flooding into the overpriced 'ye olde pubbe' or one of the chain restaurants that infest the area. More fool them if they do.

Sl40JNpnSUhoyHROWVvBqw.text: One of my best friends decided to have her birthday dinner here, and I hate to say the food wasn't good. Service was also extremely surly and slow.We arrived at the restaurant a bit early so I slipped away to speak to someone about ordering dessert and having a birthday message piped onto the plate. The "manager" just gave me a blank look and told me to talk to one of the servers who will "deal with it". Not a good start. Food didn't arrive for a good 30-45 minutes. I ordered a rare steak which came medium - so I sent it back. It took another 15 minutes for them to bring me my food. By then nearly everyone at the table had finished eating because they were so hungry! The sides were TINY, onion rings were burnt, and fries were oversalted. My friend ordered the pork belly, which was dry and came with crackling that wasn't even crispy!Dessert wasn't great either. A good sticky toffee pudding should be gooey...this one was dry and very cakey. Even though it could've been an off-day, but I definitely won't be giving Swan at the Globe another go. One of the worst meals of the year for me.

Ali2Zu8dOm6yLXA-Q8JINw.text: I was in-between 2 and 3 stars, however the extremely slow service on a weeknight decided me. There is a nice ambiance and you can't go work in those terms plus location is great and of you get a table with a view even better!  However, food and service nothing great. The food was alright, but there are better options. Service wise I already mentioned that it was slow...

FrqaPHuQwyvvpW0BhrXaHw.text: Great view of the Thames River and St. Paul's Cathedral. Me and my mum went at night, so the view was amazing. The whole atmosphere of the restaurant was great. Food was served very nicely, too. I would recommend this place to  smaller groups, and probably not children. Portion was great.We ordered the daily soup, pumpkin gnocchi, and foie gras. OH THE FOIE GRAS was amazzziiiinggggg! Service was alright. The place seemed a little busy, but we were offered what we needed. Decor was really nice too. Especially the lamps on the second floor. The lightbulbs had wings attached to them, which was really cute.After dinner, we were able to walk around and take nice pictures of the river and the view. Good dinner.

9BM1QXzySQThR-Dhnt1d_w.text: Awesome view and location but recommend just a drink here at the overpriced and not very good restaurant. Staff not too attentive. They might mean well but they seem a bit "whatever"

zydepbRda8hBGRGVj7Pmdg.text: Very cool spot/vib. Went late on a Friday night (around 9:30pm) for a bite, and kitchen was still open. My boyfriend had the fish and chips and he raved about it! If you are considering this restaurant for the view, make sure to make a reservation so you get a good spot! I did not, and I regretted it. Ok view from our table but definitely could have been better.Staff could have been a little more attentive. We sat for a good 20 minutes before anyone offered us drinks.All in all, very cool spot with great music and food. View is beautiful.

tkh8XkWVDyIEEVVA7qHw6A.text: Very good food with huge portions. Ask to see the serving size before you order because you may want to share. A fun place with excellent service and friendly staff. We would go back next time in town!

WE2NfM9tfcvgT69U1pCGCA.text: It was packed, and service was slow. However, the food was amazing, and I enjoyed my glasses of wine very much. Plan to come back in the near future - hopefully I can sneak in and miss the crowd.

JZ4UCgIxpj5SuRoGBA3tcw.text: I started looking at the reviews around the Globe for a good place to eat and the Swan wins.  I'm glad it did.   After walking around London for 5 hours I was ready to eat and sit and take my time eating. The Swan is located in the Globe entrance, the main restaurant is upstairs on the 3rd floor and is worth all the pennies. Take a break from the grime and bustle of London tourists and join the upper class at the top of the Swan. Service and food were fantastic.  I had a full three course meal with wine and 2 750ml bottles of Blenheim Palace water for £50 (including larger tip)  If I had not been so dehydrated or a big tipper the meal would have been £40.   But it was so worth the view, food, view, experience and service that it made the day complete. I had the salmon to start with, mushroom crepe for main course and the bitter chocolate moose which was superb! They bring bread to the table in little sacks which was really good, made up for the bread they served with the salmon which I did not like. Looking around the main course salmon was huge, but had a lot of bones in, the burgers and steaks looked great too.  I had a great server with a fantastic sense of humor.  I would make a point to go again if I was in the area.

fx5MV_g48BuZ8Ycq_bKitQ.text: We had an afternoon aperitif here after visiting Shakespeare's Globe.Lovely views of the Thames and St. Paul's Cathedral on a rainy night.Food was delicious, drinks even better, but service got lackadaisical in the end though they were enthusiastic when we arrived.Good, modern place though. Beautiful dining room upstairs especially.

gGYxXDilElOnKZLqd33Law.text: Got the Sunday roast which was a terrible mistake. The best things on the plate were the undercooked carrots and the cabbage. The beef was tough and dry. Expensive and not good. Go somewhere else!

HZw9O6zTojwTRLsV7BSEhA.text: Great for brunch, had the vegetarian eggs Benedict. Other options looked great for meat eaters! Pancakes and bacon, very good portions and tasty food.

cqNMf7Mr00WlsVjOp3WoyQ.text: I am hesitant to recommend Swan at Shakespeare's Globe. It's definitely designed for tourists and I was extremely hungry when I decided upon eating. The service was iffy at best and I found that my cutlery was not clean. My eggs florentine was decent but not the best. You also pay far too much for subpar food and service. Skip if you can.

photos.caption: Photo of Swan - London, United Kingdom. Eggs florentine

hiUILGKD9-zd4Tq2SoWDtg.text: Nice restaurant and fun location! We arrived around 2 pm and asked to eat upstairs but I think it's reserved for tea time only. So we ate near the bar, still great atmosphere. I had a hotdog with slaw, my husband had the tarte of the day. Both tastey, but not huge portion sizes. We were still hungry enough to order our own desserts. My husband got banana cake and I got passion fruit tart. I looooved the tart (I love passion fruit anything). The reason I didn't give 5 stars is the portion sizes vs price. Quality was good but medium for the price.

photos.caption: Photo of Swan - London, United Kingdom. Cake of the day- banana
Photo of Swan - London, United Kingdom. Sorry I already took a bite... Passion fruit tart with raspberry compote

Q27pVKCjFNS_s7nxMhXEJg.text: Had a Sunday roast dinner here and was very pleased  - we ordered a lamb roast and beef roast, served w/ all the fixings - a giant yorkshire pudding, roasted veggies, gravy - it was so comforting and well executed.  We dined upstairs and the ambiance was between formal and casual, so you could easily be dressed up, or in nice jeans.  The service was a bit strange, the waiter was least attentive, and unaware of our needs.  Thank goodness the other servers were able to bring extra gravy, and we were able to order more drinks with them.  Otherwise, great menu and great ambiance!

lIP_dGbIOJ2xk5LZnyx62A.text: I went to a dinner at the Swan with some coworkers.  It's a nice place, a bit loud by the bar but the upstairs dining room was pleasant with nice views of the Thames.  I had the pig head tartine as an appetizer, which was not bad though a bit bland. The duck breast as a main dish was an A+.  Cooked perfectly!  The beer selection left something to be desired, though I'm not the biggest fan of English ales.  I would return here.

SfT4k-5J2NdNKOngENiJhw.text: Whilst this is a lovely setting / building , the service is absolutely shoddy. We went in for a quick drink; the beer I had wasn't available so they gave me another without telling me and dashed off. I realised and returned it only to be informed after this that the beer I had wasn't available. The staff were abrupt and didn't seem to care. Thoroughly disappointed.

gcJlEceZfWm5SsdS82ia3A.text: Recreated without the use of power tools, all pegs.  Cheapest ticket in town to see a play. £5 gets you a groundlings ticket a/k/a SRO.

-UbYk2Ngp8MgPa5bf-E7tw.text: Yum afternoon tea and dessert. You can look at the river view from the restaurant. Handsome waiters ;)

photos.caption: Photo of Swan - London, United Kingdom

vHoOhiTb5MwDYtpTkacdHA.text: Probably one of the best views of London can be enjoyed from a window table here. We visited on a sunny day, and enjoyed a clear view of St Paul's Cathedral, and riverside buildings - one of the best backdrops I can imagine! The interior is light and airy, the service is efficient - we had a charming waiter. I chose the special, grilled salmon, which was beautifully done, and my friend had the spring onion tart. We saved room for dessert! What a selection of classics: cherry pie with Devon cream, Bramley apple pie and (I chose) lemon cake with pistachio ice cream. The wine list is a decent selection too.

ob0-pvaiJTbZDP8JML1f9Q.text: After a short ride on the tube, we journeyed to Shakespeare's Old Globe Theatre.  Unfortunately, only those with tickets can go into the courtyard.  I tried to con my way in by presenting my teacher's card, but since they were getting ready for a show, they couldn't let me in.  So we did the next best thing, lunch at the Swan which is part of the rather large box office.The waitress was friendly and told us to sit anywhere we wanted.  There was a very lively crowd on the balcony, but we sat inside near a window.  We ordered a couple of pints of the UK ale, which was good and hit the spot.  I ordered the fish and chips and the partner had the chicken club with bacon and avocado.  He also ordered a side of triple cooked chips.  The Brits really know how to do their potatoes right.  The chips were thick and had a firm and crispy outside.  The fish was very fresh and the meal came with mashed peas...an interesting and unique side dish.  Everything was great!  The club had a grilled chicken breast, but the roll was a little hard.When we paid the bill, there was a discretionary 12.5% gratuity added, which we didn't have to pay as it was stated on the menu.  Now we understood what those rats did at Soho Thai, but they could've been a lot more discrete and professional.  The second waitress who took my credit card told us she really wanted to go to America, especially California.  She asked quite a few questions which we were more than happy to answer.  She was also from Italy.The best part was the group of Brits who moved in from the balcony.  We told them we were leaving and the young lady shouted, "Why don't you join us!"  They then asked where we were from how we liked our "holiday," and that we really should stay for another pint.  We probably wouldn't be able to find our way back to Picadilly.Our experience at the Swan made up for that downer at Soho Thai.  We strolled away happy and content.

photos.caption: Photo of Swan - London, United Kingdom. Real fish and chips, and a half drunk beer...cheers!

un9MNwOGp05xUUuIbTkqFw.text: Had a really good dinner here before the play. The waiter was fantastic, great service.although it was a little pricey we felt it was worth it given the quality of experience and of course the setting was fantastic with our table overlooking the Thames River.

SzhOdUwrrb8k54YkzdkO3g.text: We had indian curry with naan, tasty but a bit too small portions. The atmosphere was cosy

jEUmslCwrskQKtXLT7dY8g.text: The food was delicious and service good.  I ordered the Sunday Roast, which came out perfectly, as well as the croquettes.  Really appreciated the server making sure all our orders came out speedily since we were going to a show next door. The decor is airy and open, and there is an open kitchen.  Also a long table for communal seating. Also - don't miss dessert - there's a strawberry biscuit thing that is to die for.

wuDgN47GET4abG2O979DPA.text: Entering Swan is a really positive experience as the place looks contemporary and spacious. Impressively, it even doesn't give that much of a touristy feeling as I would have expected..But the service.. Let me tell you, they should reconsider training or maybe providing training for the staff.. Nobody knew what to do.. They weren't sure where to seat us and whether we could sit at certain table. This horror continued with clearly unexperienced girl with visibly bored face and bored performance.. When I asked for fresh mint tea, they responded they don't have any. When I pointed out the bunches of fresh mint on the bar, clearly ready for being used, the waiters responded they cannot be used for the tea as they are for the cocktails.. (I mean, WHAT??!!!) So she goes and asks the barman, who really didn't let her to get few of those mint leaves..Payment seemed also a difficult task to do.. The waiters sighed loudly when we wanted to split the bill.. Seeing her bored face, we just took out our phones and calculated for her.. Food wise, well... Back to the service.. The waiters didn't know the menu... Taste wise, it was alright.. Nothing I would want to come back for as you can get that kind of food anywhere with waaaaay better experience.. Portions on the smallish side..In overall, it was a tragedy... I will not be back and recommend avoiding at all costs!Actually, I am exaggerating.. I've seen worse...

A7HJLtcBdy1qvGTah3Lh5g.text: Wow.Just wow. The structure is worth a visit, if not for a play just to see the place. It is a restored (if slightly relocated) version of the original Shakespeare's theatre that was built in the South Bank in Shakespeare's time! The actors are amazing, and even though the seats are highly uncomfortable (wooden benches) you have great visibility from anywhere at all. All plays have £5 standing tickets for spots in the ground area below the scene. Definitely worth it if you're into theatre but can't find regular tickets (plays are regularly sold out months in advance!) or just can't afford them.

6xBaJ1SjPNfr0qC9L9APuQ.text: Like many other reviewers, I was very impressed with the Globe. I went to see King Lear and enjoyed it thoroughly. I would actually say it's worth heading over just to look at the building, which is a reconstruction of the original Globe theatre, and to mosy round the gift shop, which has some original souvenirs, many of which are at reasonable prices and of good quality. It also has quite a large book and play section.If you have a bit more time, I would definitely recommend seeing a play. Tickets are very good value if you don't mind standing - I only paid a fiver, which is amazing really - less than a cinema ticket! It is a long time to stand, but I think you get the best experience if you do - it's authentic, and the actors really make the most of having groundlings, dancing and playing music amongst the crowd before the play. In terms of the production, I was very impressed. It was well directed and engaging, and the actors were really good - I was very impressed with them working on through a huge downpour of rain (and a word of warning - as a groundling, you will get soaked if it rains!).Overall, I would certainly recommend a trip to this attraction, whether you are a tourist or a Londoner. This is Shakespeare as it was meant to be seen!

q5rD9Dwz4eM1DbAsHCy9Vw.text: Had lunch at the Swan yesterday before the matinee performance of the Merry Wives of Windsor.  I was seated at a small table with an excellent view of the Thames and the dome of St. Paul's Cathedral.  The restaurant filled up quite fast so I was glad I had made a reservation.  I had the pre-theatre set lunch along with a couple of glasses of wine.  The main dish of sea bass pipperade was fantastic - cooked just right, tender with a delicious red pepper sauce, a generous green salad and boiled new potatoes.  The starter and dessert were equally tasty.  Service was friendly and attentive.  That meal has been one of the best of my whole holiday!

5PJ3KU9RePlibpplRxecqg.text: The well appointed restaurant and the bar both have enormous windows for a spectularly great view over a pretty iconic stretch of the Thames. Definitely ask for a window table when you book. Looking out over the river with pretty boats floating past, St Pauls thrusting magnificently upwards, offices lit like jewels on the far shore, it's the kind of place where eating alone would be thoroughly pleasurable. Shame the food doesn't quite live up to this magnificence. I seriously doubt Mark Sargent has ever set foot in the kitchen, the food is simply not to that kind of standard. It is good, but not really good, and definitely not great which is a shame. I started with the best dish of the night - a perfectly rare pigeon breast atop a pile of creamy lentils. The man had smoked salmon that had a pretty scattering of boiled egg yolk that added nothing by way of flavour or texture as it was simply to fine to make an impression. The other man had potted shrimp that were a little too fridge cold and not notably spiced with anything. Mains were less good, my cod had been cooked a bit too long and the dryness was not well covered by the mussel and clam soup. At alomst £20 it was a disappointment. The man liked his lamb and it's kidney. The other man ordered the special - steak and kidney pudding - which was tiny. It would easily have fitted into a teacup and came with nothing but a jug of gravy. Lucky we ordered some buttered kale as a side. didn't go for desserts but did have a cheese plate which well presented. Service was friendly but I have to say I'd return to have a drink in the bar downstairs - and order a bowl of chips to go with if I was peckish -rather than climb the stairs for dinner.

9RvyvkTK8Bj-XU4bKsRi1A.text: Well it can be overpriced (although if you see a show at midnight, you can get in for a fiver), but it has a gravitas despite looking (being!) like it was build yesterday. But I have to say, I haven't seen anything that really, truly struck me as great theatre. and not because I had to stand.

qwUC1o3sdwTBP1TQSoDiag.text: I've seen Julius Caesar and King Lear here, and they were both great. It's an exact replica of the globe of shakespeare's time, so you can't really get any more authentic for watching shakespeare. You can get a seated ticket (in which case it is advisable to pay the extra £1 to hire a cushion) or, if you're on a tight budget, you can stand at the foot of the stage, which is a really great experience too, and gets you very close to the actors. Often there are actors interspersed through the crowd at the foot of the stage, and players often enter and exit through the crowds. Really great place to experience shakespeare and some elizabethan history.

l9_GogDR__ENTR9iYnoG6A.text: Food is better than the staff's mood. If you are willingly to put up with snooty attitude the food is worth it.

p7qSziLwqL7-MgCnT4BgMw.text: Fantastic - always a quality performance and one of the most unique theatres ever. Surrounded by wooden beams, listening to that beautiful prose in the open air you can just imagine what it was like during the Bard's day. £5 tickets will get you in to stand around the stage (raised in the middle of the theatre) and there are also bench-type seats around the sides of this entirely round structure. Buying a cushion for £1 is recommended - 3 and a half hours on a wooden bench can get uncomfortable! Just saw 'Frontline' by Che Walker there. A bit of a departure from Shakespeare but equally as compelling. Always a fun time whether you're seeing a much-loved classic or something a bit new.

RYUO6qCyjD8L29DUi-9Jpg.text: Not born when shakespeare was then!? Well, this is the chance to see how his play are done. It is quite worth the money, i must say. Not only you see real plays in action, you also will experience a unique environment that this theatre gives out. There is a load of food that you can tuck into after the play. Be there on time, you won't want any play started without you.

8HDMr8FXobzacA-ougwYWA.text: Just about a decade old now, this recreation of Shakespeares Globe theatre which burned down in 1613 is a great new attraction for London visitors. Plays here can last for up to 3 hours and entry fees are very reasonable at £15 for seating (well, a wooden bench!) and £5 to be a groudling to stand (and if the weather turns get drenched too - don't forget it's an open air theatre for the most part) The whole Globe recreation is thanks to the American actor who settled in England - Sam Wanamaker, sadly he never lived to see the Globe get off the ground. There is a plaque at the globe dedicated to his memory. This is possibly the most loving recreation of a lost building that I have seen, it is very authentically built

zqrpg2yVcmMpv2kjD-DdTw.text: Watching performances at Shakespeare's Globe is a wonderful experience, that although has become very touristy, still maintains a traditional air of the theatre about it. I saw a midnight anniversary production of Hamlet at the Globe, and despite the unusual hour the services available were still good. The prices are good, very cheap for yard seats if you're prepared to stand, and slightly more for seats. The seats are more typical of the period and aren't designed with comfort in mind - they're more like school benches; hard and quite painful after a 3 hour play. Nevertheless you get some shelter if the weather doesn't hold out in the open air. Despite the time, there was a variety of foods available in the interval including good quality, authentic looking sausages in ciabatta. You should definitely see at least one play at the Globe - ideally a Shakespearian play, both for the excitement of the performance, but also for the experience of this unique venue.

CYlUk3MhteK8MZsabf10Mg.text: I was at the Globe back in 2006 with my Class, unfortunately I can't remember the name of the play. But it was gorgeous! The play was very funny and the actors where quite good. And the venue itself, I think there is nothing more to say then: Beautiful! The next time I'm in London I'll definitely be there ;)

bOcehq3Q1oFSyGjFdwcE1A.text: I would definitely reccomend the globe theatre. After a trip to watch dr Faustus, it was well worth it and has an incredible vibe and atmosphere. Standing can become tedious though so be prepared!

WN66PM6xIwDdlWx1wyVVnQ.text: I cannot recommend the Globe's production of Taming of the Shrew highly enough. Traditional shakespeare with a modern twist, highly accessible for all age groups and from shakespeare novices to enthusiasts. We were rolling in the isles! This is how it should be done!

Sin6M6uU4n_OvaxWM7GyIg.text: I chose the Swan for its location, since I was going to a matinee and and evening performance at the Globe.  And the location is the only thing to recommend this restaurant.  The menu choices were uninspired.  The roasted chicken with garlic and thyme not only was dry and overcooked, but it had never been touched with garlic, thyme or any other source of taste.  The passion fruit tart had a wet crust and was served with a blob of dense chocolate that was thick and paste-like, though the tart was begging for something light in texture.  This meal was so dreadful, it was reminiscent of dormitory food.

97xZKHMHpejfABLt5cnjqg.text: The Globe is a special day out. It's fantastic to watch the plays, with the sound of the Thames lapping in the background. It's very atmospheric andolde worldy, and would be a great trip for kid doing GCSEs or A Levels in any of the plays. If you're going in the evening, don't forget to take a coat as it can be pretty chilly. The £5 standing tickets are amazing value, though obviously, it can be tough standing for all that time. The Swan restaurant pub is also worth a look, with amazing viewsacross the river and a nice selection of wines.

n8EZs22H8By6DzzvFQzecQ.text: The Globe's production of Titus Andronicus was one of the bloodiest pieces of drama I've ever seen. Awesome! I mean, I'm talking Elizabethan Quentin Tarantino stuff. The Globe's great, as long as you get a seat and a cushion! It's got a reputation of being touristy, but really the Globe presents great performances in a fantastic, historical setting. Love it.

KrDbIJYOZhAuS_cfjK9wug.text: I must give a big THANK YOU to the Globe.......I visited it in 97 (loved it) but the best was that my teacher asked me about Shakespeare & the Globe in my oral exam in 98.....and only cause I had been there (on a private basis and he didn't know it!!!) I could tell him everything he asked for.he didn't expect this I think and was a bit amazed as we had just talked about it once(!!!!) in classes lol ;-)

Gg2-pPb0OrNmONjIS3EoOA.text: Amazing theatre and a brilliant idea, it gives you a real taste of how things would have been in Shakespeare's time. Although I would beg to differwith MaOsm who suggests groundlings or the most expensive tickets. Groundlings are super cheap but your legs will be dying by the end of the evening, and if it rains you are in even bigger trouble (it's London as if it isn't going to rain!). The next time I went I tried the cheapest seated tickets which were on a bit of an angle but for £15 that seat was worth its weight in gold.

pCJ0c6zDMSJ46rver6QJcQ.text: You can watch a real Shakespearean play in this Globe-replica all through the summer! Pretend to be part of the jostling crowd in the pit or a noble in the galleries  you're transported back 400 years to a time when Will played to all and sundry and the Globe. Apart from being steeped in history and seeing a replica of the theatre that was used all those centuries ago, the acting is brilliant and the crowd ingeniously used. Book early and there are cheap tickets available. This was a special experience.

FbguebAlYzmLDGdMS0aHQQ.text: Food is good, service... you took my food away before I was done and had asked you to leave it already and I had to ask multiple times to get a beer.

u3wlNZzSaOXMr25wnUtaPw.text: I had such a lovely time here. I came here alone to enjoy high tea and had the A Midsummer's Night Dream afternoon tea and the Sapphire Earl Grey Tea. It's definitely a lot of food for one person but I enjoyed trying everything, it's a great value. I was seated right by the window and enjoyed the view of the Thames and people watched lazily. The presentation of the meal was all star (coming in four tier and with beautifully designed desserts and sandwiches) and served on Anna Westler's custom designed tea seat for Shakespeare's Globe.

Photo of Swan - London, United Kingdom

P4_ra0LeKsG1w87CPyq-Bw.text: I had the theatre menu (2 courses).  I went for the pork belly which was tasteless and not really filling.  For dessert I had the burnt vanilla cream which was tasty but nothing that special.  The service was extremely slow.  The food took forever,  we needed to ask for water quite a few times...not impressed. The location is really nice and the view is pretty.  But I def wouldn't recommend this place.

bMd6Nme1l6Y93n6qbcxZRQ.text: Adorable spot, good after work drinks. Would love to have a meal here sometime.

UwvDLTNX2U9gcHX99VFqvQ.text: Came here for pre-theatre dinner (which you MUST book for, it will fill up!), and we had such a lovely meal upstairs in elegant restaurant, with the windows open and a lovely breeze flowing through - not to mention a view of the river and the city across it.The menu will change seasonally so there is no sense making particular recommendations - there are 2-3 choices for starter and main and dessert.  I will say that everything was prepared beautifully and excellently cooked - at £24.50 for 3 courses, it is an excellent deal for such lovely, beautiful, seasonal food.  The service was exceptional, the kind where you feel like they are truly happy to see you and wanting to make sure you have the best possible experience.  We felt very looked-after, and the meal was really a proper treat before a night of great theatre.   Why go anywhere else before the Globe - it's literally adjacent, in fact the Swan even connects to the yard of the theatre.  If you don't finish your drink before the meal is over, they'll put it in a plastic cup for you so you can take it outside and into the Globe - what service!I've been here in the past and eaten downstairs at the bar before a show, which is more of a pub food  menu but also delicious.  I also had a friend rent out the bar for her engagement party, and it was a fabulous venue for it!  But I'm biased because that was the party where I met my husband, so I guess the Swan will always hold a special place in our hearts!

vZmdiWJPTK-Y5wppVLgsAA.text: We Stopped at the Swan Bar for a quick lunch before the play. It was pretty busy, but we got our food from a very friendly person, who recommended a bottle of Sauvignon Blanc to go with our sausage logs. The logs were really good - a little on the greasy side - but very flavorful and hot. The wine was good - not great - but it was served in a plastic bottle with plastic cups so we could take it in to the theatre to enjoy the rest whilst we watched the play. The prices were a little high but it is a tourist spot and they have a captive audience. The food was good, service was good and the atmosphere was great.

dw21In7Bx7lDDnPQTX46Pw.text: Pre Shakespeare Shepard pie. The burger here is great.  They a have an adequate selection of local ales and a great selection of other cocktails and wines.The service is really good for the pre show crowd. That's a big deal really, it's a perfect spot as far as proximity to eat before a show at the globe, they actually have an exit from the restaurant that puts you inside the ticketed area for the globe. The servers know when the show starts and can accommodate a fast turn around for guests. The place gets pretty loud when it's crowded. The window seating is wonderful looking out over the river as  well as great people watching.

ePXJ25ICMjFMCVfTp-Si7A.text: Totally worth taking the tour! Our guide was friendly, very knowledgeable, and interesting!

tSzDJdETSFCoYKs1MEoHiA.text: If it is revolving or on the water you should be cautious. And that maxim applies here. I had a nice but unsurprising meal here. The location and building is thoroughly romantic and drop dead gorgeous. However, the service was erratic and the theatre menu was safe and predictable; short ribs, fish with a Beurre Blanc sauce, etc. But I had a very nice time. Damming with faint praise I may be, but you should still try it.

QhZbTts305MIpQ7jtGbWaA.text: Amazing afternoon tea with a view of the Thames. My mom loved the scones so much that she asked for the recipe and the wonderful Chef came out and gave it to her.

3SecG3I8G0haTKfbUpZYEA.text: I really enjoyed my meal at the Swan. We arrived on a Tuesday night and we got a spot for 4 at a communal table right away. I ordered fish and chips with mushy peas. The chips were thick and delicious. The peas were well seasoned. The portion was huge. My only gripe was the stools at the table were uncomfortable. Highly recommend coming here over all the chains on the south bank.

photos.caption: Photo of Swan - London, United Kingdom. Pretty flowers
Photo of Swan - London, United Kingdom. Flowers

jANjyuvaL7LTL-Q6qpsnMw.text: A walk around the Thames on a sunny afternoon can be a treat. The weather is so unpredictable that when you are blessed with a bit of sunshine and warmth, it can really lift your spirits and make you much more sociable. London Bridge is a meeting point for some of my friends and I, as it is central for us all to make our way home. It's not a bad spot at all with its bars, pubs, market, places of interest and flow of interesting folk. Whilst I have never been to the Shakespeare's Globe, I have always wandered about the idea of seeing a production outdoors, weather permitting. It must be quite the experience and yes, it is on my to-do list. For now, I was close enough having dinner at the Swan which is right next door.The Swan is a bar on the ground floor and restaurant on the first floor. They do not jest when they say they have stunning views, they do, as if you get the right spot you can see all the nearby landmarks such as St Pauls, on the north side of the Thames. Following a drink in nearby Borough Market, we visited for a meal as recommended by my dining partner. She had recently had a birthday dinner here and was well impressed. It was busy and although we did not have a reservation, we literally got the best table in the spot. For dinner it was going to be straight to the main course with me having salt marsh lamb rump, sea vegetables, Cornish potatoes and cockle butter.  I also had a size of peas and enjoyed all elements of my food. The lamb in particular was very tender. Eleanor had 400g Galloway rib eye steak, watercress, pickles shallot salad with chops and bearnaise. The food is modern British with a flair for making the simple luxurious. Because of excellent quality of the food and its proximity to the Globe, the crowd are mature and discerning diners. Swan restaurant is not a place for raucous and informal behaviour. It is much more subtle and formal than that. This is not a bad thing if you want the focus to be on enjoying the food as the lead player, which it deserves. The service also stands out too, with a nice pace in service. In terms of pricing, it is not cheap but at £28.50 for a steak, you work out if you feel this is expensive. I see Swan restaurant as a romantic location to celebrate quality time with your loved one or good food for your theatre visit.

i2Cy8IeENhXGLdK9rFspCA.text: I was in London with my 10 year old daughter, looking for a great afternoon tea, but many of the places on the top 10 lists were already booked. This one definitely fit the bill! She and I both loved it, the setting was gorgeous, and we appreciated their custom China.

photos.caption: Photo of Swan - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Swan - London, United Kingdom

Wz4nRe1cI4UdS_a0wT8Vcw.text: I came with friends and it was so good that I had to go back with my husband and another couple (dear friends of ours).  For starters, the Jerusalem artichoke soup is good, albeit a little bland (maybe it needs pepper, a spicy kick?).  But my friend and husband both got the pork crackling with apple sauce.  While they thought it was good, it was unexpectedly battered and extremely salty!  Because of the salty starter, we must've gone through 8-10 bottles of still water throughout the dinner!For the main, the Beef Wellington is perfection.  My friend's lamb was so tender that she could cut it without a knife.  And dessert wise, the panna cotta was very mediocre while the apple tart and vanilla ice cream are amazing.Extra points go to uncharacteristically great service. Beautiful views of the Thames (I had requested a nice view and was given a lovely table for my second visit).  Two sets of loos on the same floor, at opposite ends of each other) to make going a quick and convenient process, no matter which side you are seated on.  Helps a lot when you are 8 months pregnant.  All in all, a very lovely dinner and would recommend!

Oo3tKRdClDIDc72T-fm59w.text: I had avocado on toast with a poached egg, which was pleasant but not particularly interesting.  It was missing something - like chili flakes or feta - which would give it more oomph!  However, the decor and location is great and the waitress was very nice.  The coffee was pretty reasonable but not mind blowing.

photos.caption: Photo of Swan - London, United Kingdom. The view from my seat was lovely!
Photo of Swan - London, United Kingdom. Avocado and eggs on toast - the color of the yolks was a lovely orange!

G4UT08NSlemjIZsu2gQvug.text: My fiance and I stopped here while wandering the city. Our server was very friendly and attentive. Very nice space to relax, chat and have a cup of tea.

PuZgjb3kCRAhN8hOFxzRog.text: What a wonderful little place. This was recommended to me and I was worried that the place would be touristy, as it sits on the river embankment right next to Shakespeare globe theatre but once the I never got that feeling, it felt cozy, warm and welcoming. I had a Sunday roast, which was delicious, very tender and juicy beef. The portion sizes are enormous. The gentleman who was the server was very friendly and knowledgeable, if was truly a wonderful dinner overlooking the Thames and St. Paul' Cathedral. Highly recommended. Tip: ask to be seated in the dining room upstairs.

photos.caption: Photo of Swan - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Swan - London, United Kingdom

ezg9ek9QAt9Wg5xhOghnpw.text: Everyone was very pleasant and was great time for afternoon tea! Ensure to make a reservation.  They were also great at accommodating my parties dietary restrictions.

6PIgc__GtY-aJ2f4KZ3Waw.text: If you are looking for the best pancakes on the planet, check out the Swan! We popped in here during a Sunday stroll in London for a quick and tasty brunch. We were seated promptly. The service is a little sluggish, so plan accordingly with your time.I ordered the berry pancakes with whipped cream and could have happily ordered 3 or 4 more rounds - the best pancakes of my life. The pancake batter is similar to that of a victoria sponge and are griddled in butter, resulting in the most perfectly fluffy crunchy cake heaven you'll ever put in your mouth. The pancakes are then topped in a berry compote and scratch-made whip cream. The whip cream has little flecks of vanilla bean and is perfectly sweetened. No maple syrup is needed for pancakes this good.My partner ordered the eggs florentine. I tried some of his hollandaise sauce and it was divine. What a lovely spot overlooking the Thames. We sat at a booth by the window. It felt like a dream.

zuYA9LhEf9JZmEKclzvM-Q.text: Took the family of 4 last night. After a day of walking around the city. We were seated without a wait. The atmosphere was great, but the service was subpar for the price. I am surprised it was rated so highly. They refilled water just once. And we waited a very long time for the meal and then the bill after we were done. We ordered the kids meal first so our 5 year old didn't have to wait. The kids meal was extremely good for the price. Good value for: fish and chips, but was such a large fish we shared it as our appetizer, 10$GPB. Total meal without drinks was 90$GBP. The rest of the meal was presented wonderfully, in that it was fresh and beautiful. We knew it was typical British food. I just forgot that compared to my Texan taste buds, that means pretty bland.

-JlZGKjPl3NhrxfCqJWlYQ.text: Waiter failed to check on us while he made his rounds checking on every other table around us. Duck leg was good, nothing extraordinary. My partner's cod was dry and tasteless. Not a pleasant afternoon.

BGKozEi2mogUnBcR0kzHAg.text: I wanted to experience a proper tea while in London and ended up at Swan Shakespeare's Globe after touring the Tate Modern. Served from 11:30 am - 3:30 pm Monday thru Saturday and 2:00 - 3:30 pm on Sunday, it was the perfect afternoon pick-me-up. The restaurant itself is two levels, with the tea taking place on the top, more formal level. We were seated near a window which provided a great view of the River Thames and surrounding landmarks. For 26.50 pounds, we got a three tiered display of sandwiches, biscuits and desserts. We also ordered two pots of tea and, since I was feeling celebratory, a glass of Love Potion, a mix of Earl Grey infused gin, honey from the London Honey Co, blackberry puree and prosecco, topped with fresh blackberries. It was SO GOOD. Let's just say my dream of tea was more than fulfilled. It was such a nice respite from touring London and I would definitely recommend. Although this spot may be on the pricier side, the ambiance, service and quality of food was more than worth it!

photos.caption: Photo of Swan - London, United Kingdom. Tea for two!

dnBeu4KjCGSb17vuuhBqpg.text: We only had a drink as they were booked out , however the service was really nice and the wine decent. They did make an effort with checking in on us frequently and looking out for tables to sit to get a chance for a meal. The view is very nice as you're directly looking onto the Thames which is lovely by night. Would definitely recommend if you need a break from walking around south bank or looking for a more decent pub than the average english pub.

DpcA-BAWg_L7nAAxE-ThxQ.text: Service stinks... wait staff was great, but the rules they fall under are a joke. We got there at 10mins to noon and was told we could not order lunch, so we ordered a small something waiting for 12Noon to roll around. Once lunchtime rolled around, she took our order, but then we saw others ordering off a different lunch menu than we were offered. One thing we ordered were the cracklings (after noon because we were told we could not order before noon). When it came out it was cold, (telling me they were pre-cooked) so the waitress' story that "the chef hasn't arrived" to cook all the food was a crock. Plus, having been in F&B, if you're a chef showing up right at noon to start prep and cooking for lunch, you're about 3-4 hours late. After we left, we walked by the kitchen windows and saw several "chefs" running around making lunch. It's terrible when you KNOW you're being lied to.

LyDSLioMt-VNUR-xss8hSw.text: Though we initially chose the Swan for its proximity to Shakespeare's Globe Theater, this elegant restaurant, located on property, is by no means merely riding on the coattails of the famed stage's popularity. With its timeless, romantic atmosphere & food so impeccably prepared, I've no doubt that the Swan could succeed in the middle of nowhere. Aromatic rosemary & onion flavors their sliced bread (& ya gotta love a place that serves room temperature butter!) Many compliments for his ribeye, & my tart, topped with a beautiful assortment of roasted veggies, was absolutely delectable. The light, delicate layers of puff pastry became rich when coated in red wine butter sauce. And speaking of butter, my side of heritage potatoes were coated in the perfect marriage (or rather, ménage à trois?!) of butter, oil, & herbs. We had dinner upstairs, but should you have time restraints, the abbreviated bar menu available on the ground level looked just as lovely. Spectacular views, wonderful service, & maximum flavor in each forkful; needless to say, the Swan is a charmer.

-8g9_eiSui5TbGmJwgnTVQ.text: My brother and I came here as we were exploring our first area after we settled into our hotel and we found this place on an empty stomach.  We were actually looking for sunday roasts and this place had it, which was really convenient.  So, we ordered that and some mulled cider too, both of which were new to us.  Without any point of comparison, I will just say that I found the food to be very delicious and the mulled cider was pretty good. My roast came with a side of cauliflower gratin and had, on the plate, potatoes, yorkshire pudding, kale, and bone marrow.  All of it was quite good, but I liked my brother's roast better.  He got a crispy pork belly roast with kale and potatoes and an applesauce dip.  Overall, I enjoyed this place and would consider coming back. In writing this review, I noticed other stuff on their menu that I might try out next time.

4WfCqjw2CyqEE_vwD6cFfQ.text: We had the hotel concierge make reservations after they recommended The Swan for afternoon Tea (when we found out the London Ritz was full). We are glad we went to The Swan instead! I wouldn't even consider PM Tea as a meal if it weren't for my wife, but the Swan has a very well prepared "gentleman's Tea" that includes a BBQ beef slider, scotch egg and a pint of appropriately paired ale. No complaints here, as my wife is happy with her multi level terrace of treats (mine was on a cutting board). Go enjoy an afternoon on the Thames!

MwxYZsCxL41IWgXDWzo6WQ.text: Picturesque location near the river. Pleasant vibe. Cocktails were tasty. Charcuterie board was interesting in a good way. Food was good - shepherd's pie, fish & chips - but under seasoned.Very friendly service.

0KcgE8bj_PDmFCV6DCIqFA.text: Touristy during the day but trendy/ hipster during the evening. I came here three times during my stay in London. Yes,  I am both a glutton and a creature of habit when on vacation. First time, to grab dessert and a drink before the the play "Comus: A Masque in Honour of Chastity". As part of my solo dirty 30 celebration.Second time, after the play for a bit of warm soup and two cocktails (2 of the Rose Sangria and does taste like rose!). The third time, for an actual proper meal... I had the soup again, the main course special: pheasant,and apple pie with vanilla ice... My favorite was the peasant because it had a nice umami sauce with rosemary. The second favorite part of the meal was the dessert with its fresh out of the oven pastry and delicate apple goodness.Also the people you meet are worth it. Ranging from the locals to Aussies to drunk out of their minds folks, it won't be a dull evening. So, I recommend coming here during the evening if you want a savory English meal or a pint.

Tea was my favorite part, very relaxing place.We didn't try but the Midsummer Night's Dream desert platter looked really good.We had chocolate pudding, very similar to lava cake, delicious.Service was great.

stsvY6-0O1zK4p0UqdtYSQ.text: Interesting place. It's riverside with a gorgeous view, but the seating in the comfy little lounge area is neither comfortable nor tall enough to see the views. Cocktails a bit spendy, and they add on a service fee. We tried two of their signature cocktails and weren't entirely impressed; one left a very strange after taste. The strange thing-  the old wooden chest they have available for a table is curved, so you can't put your drink down.  Our server was attentive. I don't think I'd return, although other customers did look happy.

Ep49Haw6aq7r7e3xRbYtWQ.text: We visited the Swan Restaurant after watching a matinee performance.  It was convenient as it was raining but I had booked a table. At night you'd have a good view of the lights on the opposite riverbank The pre-theatre menu is overpriced for the mediocre food on offer. We both ordered the Herb Crusted Sea Trout with Potato & Cucumber Salad, Pickled Mustard Seeds with Squid Ink and Garlic Mayonnaise. As soon as we saw it we said "It's salmon" and the arrogant waiter's reply was "Trust me, it's trout".  It was definitely salmon as I only eat fish and it was slightly overcooked. The amount of salad was about a heaped tablespoon and the mayonnaise was in a tiny dish, so not a big meal. For dessert I had Baked BlackBerry Tart, Frangipane with cream. I've had better and the pastry crust was very hard.  We were annoyed by the frequency of waiter visits to top up water and wine. Surely we could have looked after our own water. There are plenty of other restaurants near the Bankside so I'd give it a miss unless you want a good view after dark. Beware: they add 12.5% service charge is added.

vIuPDINo2hdoqyOq9e2lZQ.text: I am always on the look out for romantic brunch restaurants and by the Thames is always a win win situations for things to do after and the beautiful scenic walk there. But sometimes I want something more casual, no fancy dress code, somewhere I can relax and be cosy and Swan at the Globe is always one of those places I return to for that. It is a mix crowd of people depending on what time you come. I am recommending an early brunch as it's definitely more quiet and peaceful before the bar gets busy and the louder crowd comes in, especially during the weekends for pre-theatre drinks.They have recently refurbished their upstairs restaurant if you prefer more formal dining but I haven't been upstairs to comment. One thing I find myself drooling for are their beautiful rich yolky poached Legbar eggs. It must be the reason why their eggs Benedict is known to be their signature dish being voted top 10 in London by the Evening Standard too.We started with a mocha and an Americano presented in two different classic mugs like I entered someones's home. Very cute. Mocha was rich and chocolatey and Americano smooth and fragrant. Good coffee! For food we ordered:Eggs florentineJust like how I ordered them 3 years ago. The muffin was light and fluffy, toasted do was nice and crisp around the edges. The spinach was fresh, velvety and cooked to perfection. But the highlight of it all were those two large poached eggs sitting on top. The yolk came out blood orange, deliciously rich and thick. The accompanied hollandaise sauce did it much justice adding that lovely creaminess to it and bringing everything together.Full English breakfastIt didn't have all the fancy presentation or looked like much. But the beauty was inside as everything tasted great. Juicy portobello mushroom, silky creamy scrambled eggs, sweet crispy bacon, the sausages were very flavoursome, full of herbs and texture and same goes for the black pudding. It came with a jar of baked beans so it was kept warm inside but you ate it and a slice of toast. Service was great and efficient. We even asked for more of that delicious crisp fluffy toast to accompany it all and they gave it to us without no questions.Buttermilk pancakes, berry compote and vanilla cream. These were slightly disappointing. The pancakes themselves were slightly too dense and bland. The berries were tart but refreshing if you like that kind of sourness. The vanilla cream did a good job balancing out the flavours though. Overall I really enjoy Swan at the Globe. Although it is right next to the Globe theatre itself, a big tourist attraction, prices are still affordable. If you manage to grab a booth table and able to enjoy the comfy leather couch seating then you can find yourself here letting time fly by. Otherwise it might be a shared table with other diners next to you. Whatever it is just order an eggs Florentine/Royale/Benedict. You won't regret it.

YMnpHP2QISl93sxgn6LKVg.text: After completing the arduous jet journey from Miami to London, we ended up here as my daughter is studying/performing at the Globe. As the name implies, it is conveniently located in the Globe complex and near the Tate Modern. It is a cozy space  with a lovely view of the Thames and St. Paul's cathedral. For lunch I had an excellent soup (Jerusalem artichoke with spinach and hazelnut pesto. I had a half pint of prawns...they were ok but then I'm spoiled with locally sourced Florida Keys seafood. Maybe it's me but the service seemed inattentive but my daughter says the Brits are unobtrusive in that way. It was pricey but I'm attributing that to the location. This seems like a good place for a pre or post show meal.

QPly--I8jeF86qUFe0KzFw.text: Had such an amazing dining experience here! Got to have some afternoon tea with friends. While visiting London, we all knew we needed to have afternoon tea. The places we looked at were all booked in advance, unfortunately. And after attempting a different location and getting rejected since they were fully booked, we happened across Swan. They too were fully booked as well, but the hostess immediately attempted to find us a table despite this fact. And after a few minutes, she came back with a spot for us! So A+ customer service already!! The bottom plate was definitely my favorite of course. The savory foods, ughhh those small finger sandwiches are to die for. On the second plate were the scones, which were absolutely delicious! They melted in your mouth. On the final third plate on top were the sweet sweet desserts. All of them tasted amazing! The restaurant was I believe three floors, and the ambiance of the whole place is a big WOW! Modern, gorgeous and cute all at the same time. Also, the location of the place is walking distance to many tourist areas.. Service is amazing, the tea was great and they offered different choices. I also got a cocktail or 'love potion' as they called it, which was super good (& strong hahah!).
