9O0PMlEOXUOI2Go0wmCBMg.text: Scotch eggs, thats why I came here and they were oh so good. Never had them before but they are damn good! They make them the classic way, wrapped in a sausage crust. Apparently there are many variations but this is the classical style.This is now my second favorite way to eat eggs, eggs Benedict would be my first. But Scotch eggs don't necessarily need to be eaten for breakfast, they make a good anytime snack and go well with a pint of beer. Ended up getting several plates of these tasty treats. The Swan is a lovely place with a great view of the Thames and located next to the Globe theater. They have wooden bench seating in the middle, booth on the sides and outside seating is available in the nautical themed space. They also serve up a good fish and chips. We were here for lunch but also visited late while taking a stroll down the river walk. We stopped in and had a few drinks, place is very lively. It is a very open space and nicely decorated, the staff were super friendly and there seems to be a good mix of people who visit the place.

EFluTmXBZU6MeSw73lByMQ.text: 09/13/17Not far from Tate Modern Museum. This is the restaurant that is connected to Shakespeare's Globe with gorgeous views of the Thames river and St. Paul's cathedral. This two story restaurant a partner with the Shakespeare Globe Theater for over a decade. Contemporary British cuisine is showcased here. Morgan I think was the Maitre D but he ended up being our waiter. He was unbelievably knowledgeable, friendly and an expert in customer service. I can not impart how truly wonderful, attentive and friendly he was. We continued to rave not only about him but about the food. There are bites in our life that leave an indelible memory on our brain. Memories of lovely and luscious, delectable, savory and sweet treats play in my mind. This was my families first time to London and our fist time to this restaurant. We were leaving London and my daughter and I wanted to try a high tea before we left. I made the faux pas of not dressing up. I humbly apologized to the hostess and to Morgan who was beyond kind and gracious and told us not to worry! Thanks Morgan for making us feel welcome and understood. Was super excited to try the new menu for high tea that was made to compliment a Midsummer Night's Dream. The dinner ware had Midsummer Night's Dream character's on them. I was super amused and wish that my photo's of the plates and flatware turned out. Even the menu had the same design as our plates. My daughter and I have never had high tea. We felt it was a must do before we left London. High tea is a shared platter. We ordered tea. I ordered Sapphire Earl Grey my daughter had the Egyptian mint. My husband and son ordered off the main menu. My husband ordered the special of the day. My son got slow cooked short rib or beef with braised carrots, mashed potatoes and pickled onions.Our meals arrived together. My daughter's and mine was a three tier platter. The first platter was dessert, the second scones and the first savory items. On our menu was wild mushroom and leek quiche, Wiltshire ham with grain mustard and pea shoots, oak smoked salmon with lemon pepper butter on dark rye, Clarence court egg with mayonnaise and watercress. These little bites were so delectable and tasty that I had to close my eyes and savor each and every bite. My daughter and I were beyond pleased. I love salmon but that one was my least favorite. The second tier had mulberry and plain scones with clotted cream and strawberry jam. This was the first time we had a British scone. These scones were flaky, lightly crisp around the edges with a light and airy center. The clotted cream and jam on top just put them over the top. Thanks again to Morgan who when asked what the etiquette was on how to enjoy the High Tea. He was so kind and full of information. He was right the jam and clotted cream really make the scones heaven. The desserts at the top were divine. They were rose infused raspberry and lemon cake, Elderflower and violet macroons, glazed white chocolate blondie with caco nibs, blackberry compote with lavendar cream. I know it doesn't sound like a lot of food but it was. I was not able to finish both of my scones because it was so much food.The desserts were so light, airy and luscious. Again we were closing our eyes to savor the flavor and moment. The cost seemed to be about average when I was researching High Teas in London. I can only rave about our high tea or about Morgan. Would I go back? You bet I would. While we were munching down our little finger foods off the High Tea platter we could hear my husband and son oohing and ahhing over their own plates. Can I just say look at my pictures and I am sure you can understand why they were in love with their meal. I truly hope that Morgan is give Kudos!! Thanks so much Swan Shakespeare Globe for a wonderful, superb meals that will leave a memory that will last a lifetime or the next time we go to London!!

2vamUddwhawQz8PFlljnjw.text: Came here on a Sunday evening to enjoy their Sunday Dinner offer of 2 courses for £25. They also offer 3 courses for £28. I had the lamb roast dinner as a main and it was delicious. Great roast potatoes and I was very pleased to see a Yorkshire pudding included in the "trimmings". My lamb was flavoursome, if a little fatty.  I opted for a meringue and fruit desert. It was good but my friend had the brown sugar tart which was delicious and immediately gave me dessert envy. Lovely service and the staff were very attentive. They checked on us and get us topped up with wine throughout the meal. Finally, the thing that absolutely makes this place a must visit, is the view from the dinner table. Beautiful scenes of the river and the stunning skyline across London.

g_zAUIUilBMj709ccE7rWA.text: We were looking for a place to eat after visiting the Tate Modern and The Shakespeare Globe.  The Swan Shakespeare is connected to the Globe.  We chose to sit in the bar instead of the restaurant since we were looking to have a reasonably priced lunch.  We compared the menus and the bar menu items were half to two thirds the price of the restaurant menu - different menu items.The food was very good.  The Sandwich of the day served with 3 salads of the day was delicious, generous in portion and it was a relative bargain at 8 pounds and 50 pence.The Swan Shakespeare also had 1/2 pint options for their draught beer and cider that is priced fairly - great to have the half pint option to have for lunch.Service was friendly and efficient.  The seating was very comfortable.  We had a view of the River Thames.I highly recommend The Swan Shakespeare when visiting Tate Modern or Shakespeare Globe.

3pzayjkQR6ijfswsOor6PA.text: Literally writing this review as I'm dining at the restaurant right now (after ordering our food) because I'm just that blown away. Marvelous space overlooking the Thames. Service thus far has been excellent.Update: the food was top-notch.Great, great meal...

l0iSjL7xCOC2T14683ypzQ.text: Fantastic service (top notch), wonderful food.... and the best kids' menu!

cqTZV20_bD9uUS9rleOBKw.text: As a tourist and a theater fan, I had to check this place out. I sat in the communal seating area. Though there are more private tables. I got the Shakespeare Ale and the Fish and Chips, because again, tourist.  They had wifi. I tried to buy tickets for the show that night but it was sold out. The staff was friendly and accommodating. They didn't rush me. The bathroom is upstairs and has a lot of photos on the walls leading up to it of past shows. I spent a lot of time looking at those.

qsAEi2SzX9zhwGN6x6oCDw.text: Came here after the play and was super pleased with the ambience and the food. Its was very romantic and our table came with a view. The food was delicious!! Highly recommend this place! Even thought we were more than 15min late for our reservation because of the play but they were very friendly and got us a table. Again, highly recommend it!!!

s67orHbBXikrSzZf7TOBXQ.text: After exploring the Globe on our own, we joined a very informative tour led by a friendly and knowledgeable staff member. The tour takes you all over the premises while the leader points out and explains any significant architectural aspects, the Bankside (area where the theatre is) lifestyle, costumes + props from plays. We didn't get to go near the stage too closely because there was a rehearsal going on, but that area is normally a part of the tour.

zcGekhbHTLGTr3S79X1E_g.text: I did the tour last year and enjoyed it very much. The guide was very informative and also friendly and happy to answer questions. I have not yet been to a show there but will definitely do it soon.

fHAS6XkWguEmNdjC37XgSw.text: This is a great and authentic venue. The atmosphere inside the place is definitely worth the cost of getting in!! Although any play can be seen here, seeing a Shakespeare here is just amazing. Although standing tickets are really cheap, sacrificing the extra money for seats is really worth it.

jRT6Q1Yc_B1ovtoUJy8EZA.text: What a superb place to visit.I went to the Shakespeare's Globe for free because i went to the Thames Frost Fair and you get free entry to Globe.I remember this place being restored and could not wait for it to open.I have not seen a proper play here , but when we had a walk around , they were some men playing some old instruments which i enjoyed.There shop is great and sell dvds and cds and theatre related things.The Shakespeare Globe was a great place to see and i will deffiently be coming back to see a play in the near future.

2AT6dfl3oNhzF9qrK6Ci3w.text: This is a fantastic way to experience a Shakespearian play in London. It's for all the family and even the younger ones as there are children's tours available of the adults wish to watch a play and believe that the children probably won't stand through it. Remember that's based on the original plans so it's not the most luxurious of theatre houses and the seats that are available aren't that comfortable so be warned !! However, it's a wonderul experience and offers plenty of extra tours and the like for those who cannot stay for an actual play, although I would always recommend the play if you can. It's not too expensive and takes care of a good half a day of good family entertainment.

XvSnmVGrm_D25mkT5tpKbQ.text: Location and views are amazing. Attended (and took pictures at) a wedding and reception here. Brilliant service and friendliness all day long, great cheese and meat plates, amazing location and just made a brilliant day even more brilliant.

SeD62D53YKmfnw0aHqmRQA.text: What an amazing place. The atmosphere alone is worth the cost of entry. I would recommend seeing any play here, but a Shakespeare is just magical. If one is not into doom and gloom, Love's Labour's Lost is a light hearted romantic comedy that is a must... Yard tickets are great, and can be picked up for £5, but be prepared to stand for the entire performance.

kBigXX4x3r-MxvVKPeVZgg.text: I would just like to comment on the recent tour I went on at the Globe. The tour guide was great, you could tell she really had a passion for Shakespeare and a genuine love for the reconstructed building. An excellent start to learning about Shakespeare, his plays and London in the 16th century.

WALKBoUhmV059FDdlfKK2g.text: Lovely and enchanting and everything a Shakespearean fan could want, but do make the trip to the south bank count with a visit to the Tate Modern or maybe the NT as well! Both only a short walk from the Globe.

4EFw0eiYlZgJJCyiyzbSqA.text: This is a great place. You can view authentic recreations of Shapespeare's play here. You should watch a play here and enjoy the atmosphere in there. Plays are usually held during the day. Tickets are pretty pricey but it is worth it. You can get cheaper tickets for a play but you have to stand for the whole play. It is a great way to enjoy it though. You can also go on a tour of the backstage area and the theatre of course.

7BmlsT9u5cmKv3uqO7-FfQ.text: For those with an art and literary interest, this is the place to go in London. Yes, thats a real thatched roof and the performances are nigh sublime. they even use old methods of stage contruction to keep it all the more authentic. A little pricey, but worth it. A good stones throw from Tower Bridge if you take the right route.

2kQ217vDW07J8YFPgYhzbA.text: I've never been to the actual theatre, but I have been to the restaurant which is in the upstairs part of the theatre. The food is truly excellent and the service fantastic. We had a special deal which meant we got the meal for a very reasonable price, but normally the food is quite pricey. However, on this occasion, I feel it would be worth it as the views across the river are stunning and this really is a very special restaurant to eat in. It is ideal for a special or romantic occasion. I must try the theatre soon!

nIxH7ncN4cAPjgTKJAL7FQ.text: I think this is an amazing venue (such a great idea to keep it as authentic as possible) and such a brilliant attraction in London. However, I agree with some of the others and wouldnt stand again. I went at school and seem to have forgotten how tiring it was when i went recently.

jfuupyJ1HJMOZNdiocZWHA.text: Should be great, initially was great, but just a tourist attraction now really. Worth it once, but look elsewhere for great theatre. The actors tend to be a bit below par too - they'll cast their Macbeth based on his classical work in Hollyoaks over a genuinely capable performer.

wHuDEQXSKnJm2Wdeb1-g7Q.text: fantastic olde worlde charm, a real visible sense of early english history, worth a peek by anyone interested in theatre, history and romance

fN8XrhHNjPQwm6DSiAPszA.text: the one and only place to see the best shakespeare plays and it is fantastic every time i deffenetly reccomend it

LoNjXLLQwbfTg5x6jERubA.text: Had fate not stepped in, we'd have probably ended up at a completely different restaurant and would never have got the chance to end up very stuffed and satisfied after a huge three course Sunday lunch. As it was London Restaurant Festival, we decided to treat ourselves for lunch for a friend's birthday, and this was the first place that was open and had space. And, boy, were we glad about that. The setting looking out over the Thames is absolutely beautiful and the food matched this. Starters of scallop gratin, potted shrimp, smoked salmon and leek and potato soup (with a poached egg), were all playful and delicious, while the mains - roast beef and pork belly, were all devoured and were spot on. The carrot and swede mash was a particular highlight. Desserts were also delicious, but we probably didn't quite do them justice, given how stuffed we were. Two of our group were in raptures about the Sherry Trifle, the crumble and the chocolate mousse were both delicious, although the sticky toffee pudding was a little dry. The only real complaint was the service was a tad slow at times. But the food was delicious and given it was a very lazy Sunday lunch, this wasn't as big an issue as it might have been. I'd love to try the regular non-Sunday menu.

Srg_P9px7ZKXRlx3JyHjyg.text: 5 pound a ticket is very good value. (You do have to stand thought) It has so much history about this place, so if you are in any way in Kline to a bit of English history, you have to come here

EGS70ACyjaCIu0SAe6SHOA.text: My favorite place in the world. i would go every week if I could. Have recently found out that you can volunteer to work here in your spare time. All i need to do is find some time which is spare and i will. The moment you arrive you are taken in by everything. It's so authentic even down to paying for cushions to sit on as the wooden benches aren't renowned for their comfort. If you have the legs you can get a ticket for the pit but i would recommend paying more to sit. Shakespeare, legend. Simples!!!

tyWE_X9iYd-28F5JyRakPw.text: A great place indeed ! This is something I'd meant to do for awhile, but never got round to I'm very glad I did. The tour of The Globe was excellent ! The guides are enthusiastic and knowledgeable. I loved it.

qFg2ETeZCT42q9Z3Tsc70A.text: As everyone else has said before me eloquently, the Globe is a super and special place. I went last Friday to see Macbeth and was stunned by the production, the acting and the atmosphere. Thrilling. All I will say is if you can go: do. If you can afford to grab a seat then invest in a cushion. And whatever you do, unless it's a barmy midsummer's night, bring a big jumper or a coat. I was f-f-f-freezing. It was so worth it though.

0mfGVIlz16bsIE9d6l2tDg.text: WOWThink about the history and the people that have been here.. sat in these seats and heckled the actors.. its awe-inspiring

PyDtilYTWMPVsrMCI97FiQ.text: Excellent value and a wonderful performance of Henry V. I would recommend this to anyone. SUPERB

ICn_PhIoKhrrs5d3Qo7jiQ.text: What can I say  excellent from location to menu to service

Q2aT5P92JVX2gONoHpMK3g.text: Wonderful tourist attraction and a must visit in London. You can top off your visit with lunch in the Swan connected to this site.

Hj4_yY88Q1QpngLl7VryNQ.text: I truly enjoyed this place. We had a lovely view of St. Paul's Cathedral, despite the cloudy day, and the food did not disappoint. My husband and I both selected the salmon salad. The salads arrived with a generously sized, lightly peppered piece of mozzarella on top, savory pieces of salmon, crisp bell peppers, lettuce, etc.  The dressing was a perfectly rendered, buttery golden vinaigrette. My husband's not a big fan of dressing, and he found this one to be absolutely delicious. We both left with delighted palates.

uQrkhYws5UwUFa_SwiFYzw.text: The biggest selling point here has to be the location and the views. We managed to bag a first floor table by the window, with gorgeous views of St Paul's and the Millenium Bridge - definitely worth requesting this when you book. Having said that, the food ain't half bad either, as you'd expect when the head chef is a Ramsey protege like Mark Sargeant. The menu consists of solid British fare plus some quirky items such as Elizabethan mutton casserole,and kipper pate. The highlight for me was a seafood cocktail with a nice feisty gazpacho. Lots of flavour, good ingredients and a novel concept - nice little dish. They also often have very good Top Table deals so it's worth watching out for those. We ate there at 8.30 on a Friday night and were still able to get 40% off the food. Very tidy!

-biOtkvNINTiZOqBh6zi8A.text: I have passed this restaurant so many times and finally decided to pop in here this afternoon for tea with a friend. It was lovely and one of my favorite tea experiences in London so far. The atmosphere was perfect for a rainy day, warm and comforting with lots of seating and soothing lighting. Our server, Emma, was extremely nice and warmly welcomed us and looked after us throughout our experience. I got a pot of English breakfast tea and a huge piece of carrot cake and my friend got the mint tea and a scone-all for £12. I am confused as to why this place was labeled with £££, I thought it was quite affordable, even the main menu items weren't over the top. The Swan is has a very versatile clientele, men in business suits grabbing a pint after work, ladies who lunch, theater goers having an early dinner, everyone seems to go here and there's something for everyone. Check out their drink menu when you go; it is full of very creative and Shakespeare themed drinks.

T-d9-qZF1lgRflarLwJgtQ.text: Visiting the Globe is a great experience and something you must do if you're interested in Theatre or Shakespeare's plays (watching them performed really makes them come to life). The benches in the theatre are quite uncomfortable, especially if you've been sitting on them for a couple of hours. I would recommend getting one of the wooden seats with cushions if you intend on sitting down. You can buy standing tickets very cheaply but you're not allowed to sit on the floor if you get tired so be careful! There are stalls outside selling drinks and snacks. The atmosphere is buzzing - a fab day out!

JWrrphQ48b9Xo25zaYqOjQ.text: Great experience. The Brit writers book awards was held there recently and it was an amazing event really well done guys.

3RLMVIW5yjlms0Ih6gZRwA.text: Most people have already covered the main points about the Globe. So I'll just add my tuppence worth. It truly is a wonderful addition to a great city. Kitted out like the original open air theatre, this is the only place to go in summer for a spot of Shakespeare. There are £5 standing tickets for every show, which is awesome value. Some of the the shows are 3 hours long! The down side is that you have to stand for that long, but to be honest, it's the only way to see a show there. For those who chicken out and get cushioned seats, they miss out on the best of it with the groundlings. One of the best shows i ever did see was at the Globe. It was a production of Pericles (which I hadn't seen before), directed by Kathryn Hunter. On the night that I went to see it, Corin Redgrave, who was the principal actor playing old Pericles, had been rushed to hospital, and the then artistic director Mark Rylance stepped into the role. It was wonderful. Really, brilliantly, marvellously, awesomely wonderful. Since Dom Dromgoole has taken over the artistic directorship, the programme has become significantly more edgy and violent. Not necessarily a bad thing. The Globe also puts on new writing that has a basis in Jacobean styles. As with everything creative, sometimes it's good and sometimes it ain't. I walked out at the interval at the press night of a new show last year. As much because it was boring as it was because it was raining. It is great when you find a show that's worth standing in the rain for though.

Jffx8bNkX-IrXkmpixJBTQ.text: I haven't been to the Globe in 5 years - so this review is a) as an attraction/learning experience, andb) possibly outdated? I went to the Globe with school when studying Shakespeare, and I found it so fascinating.If you have even the smallest of background knowledge on the original Globe, you can come here and build on that incredibly until you feel like your head will explode. I am a huge fan of Elizabethan London history, so perhaps it captivates me more than the average person, but I found the Globe to be one of the most inspiring, overwhelming and wonderful places in London.

W1zh1-bHhIsgV6CFewtT9g.text: Every year on St george's day, which also happens to be shakespeare's birthday, they have an open day here, and you can get on stage and say a couple of lines (or couplet). I did it one year and it was great, but I couldn't help thinking that is seemed a bit big for an Elizabethan building. It probably is, but nobody complains. However, there is no need for the benches to be as bloody uncomfortable as they are.I've not seen any plays here, which was remiss of me, but it must get a bit hard on the bum or the feet, with little chance of refreshment. And of course it is open air when you stand, so you take your chances with the weather.

OilNuUHMQZkTl40hZ8zOmQ.text: What a great venue! I've seen two shows here and been standing both times. It only costs £5 to stand and watch but be warned it can be tiresome after 3 hours standing on a concrete flour. I suggest getting in as early as possible and getting a place either near the front where you have more space to sit down at the interval, or right at the back where you can at least lean on the partition to the seating. The plays are well acted and good use of the venue is used. Refreshments are available but are pricey. A shop is inside and there are some good quality souvenirs available at reasonable prices.

0LwGVGB1Qn-FyoKthO1oOg.text: This review speaks of the Globe strictly as an attraction, not as a theatre. I got to visit right after it was built in the late 90s and unfortunately, there were no plays being shown during my short stint in London. This bummed me out hugely, but I hope to go see a play here next time I visit. As an attraction and a tour, the Globe is a must-see in London. The theatre is a real site to behold. It was built based on the exact dimensions of the original which burned down a long time ago. It wasn't built in the same location, but from what I remember, it wasn't built that far away from where the original stood. The workmanship of the building, the artistry of the woodwork was very much felt, as was the sense of history it represented, even though it was a reproduction. I really look forward to seeing a play here next time I'm in London.

LV-hoV8ABp9lornUKmZ9zw.text: The guided tour they do round the theatre is brilliant, you can go all round the backstage area, and you get a real feel of how it used to be..as far as plays go, is a bit of a mixed bag! I have seen plays both as a 'groundling' and from a seat. I did not enjoy standing about on the groundpartly because it was really really long, but mostly because I am a bit short, and the stage is really high, so I felt like I was missing loads of stuff as I couldnt really see..also I got spat on by an actor!! From the seats it was better, but if you are too high up, you can loose some of the words, as the lack of roof makes the sound a bit funny. That said it is definately worth the experience, and there is no where else where theatre is quite the same!

bQffVUmbCHXhzJWclu-pAw.text: Great atmosphere and good selection of wine.  We sat here for hours chatting and drinking wine.

k2NdbpVsrGODVjW-FCgXSg.text: We had some food and drinks in the restuarant on teh first floor and I was stunned by the view over St. Paul's and the beauty of the place. The quality of food and drink was good and the service was good (efficient and attentive) even though they were clearly out of their depth as to the food they served (no bread plates with teh bread and do't even try to make them filet the fish). but if you are not a snob and can ignore these, you will have a lovely dinner.

photos.caption: Photo of Swan - London, United Kingdom

WWJX2BYavDbeEPr3tkckzw.text: The building is fantastic, and to actually watch a theatrical event in this setting is magical. Do pay the extra for a seat though. It is not at all pleasant standing in the rain watching a show. From the seating area, it's grand. This is a must-see must-experience place for London natives and visitors.Hope to go this summer to another performance.

DRSftBAoqX9ML-vsU82Plw.text: I can't say I've tried the food (and couldn't do better than the review below!), but the Swan also makes for a decent wine/cocktail bar. The decor treads the fine line between trendy and kitsch (the angel-winged lightbulbs somehow work) and creates a nice space the views across the Thames to St Paul's don't hurt either. With a decent wine and cocktail list, it's no surprise all the window seats are taken by loved-up couples. During daylight hours, the outdoor balcony would be a great place to sun yourself while sipping something cold. A welcome respite from the string of chain restaurants along this stretch of river!

CFFYhbcbNhABWj8XeDp--A.text: What a beautiful view & setting! Highly recommend it to everyone & anyone! Such a delight, really loved my afternoon! Everything was to die for!

5g0xi20ZKGVoG8-sJt9JmA.text: Just an unbelievable experience !When you enter the theatre its like a step back in time, very well made.Standing infront of the stage is a much bigger expirience than sitting, you will forget the time while watching any play.The price for the unbelievable result is more than justified !I dont want to tell to much,so just go there, when you are in London !

9sR7BFHNJV5x0tS9Exu7bg.text: Eh.  You're paying for the location, and view of the river.  Tourist trap really but at least the drinks are strong.... :-)

THNzIRnGISzbig9o-arBEg.text: We love this place.  It's a seamless transition to the plays - no worries about whether you're going to be served in time for the performance, etc., and it completes the experience of the Globe.  River view is very atmospheric.  The food is fresh and well-prepared, and the bread is gorgeous.  Definitely recommend.

RT83QQxYjJh4674Kpcc6ag.text: Really with the good reviews, Yelpers?! Did I just have this place on an off day? The decor and location, yes, is lovely, but the food - blegh. My lemon sole was horrible and the appetizer -- baby shrimp in brown butter -- was cold! I didn't know what to expect but I'll tell you this, it wasn't fishing out teeny tiny little salty shrimp from a ramekin of congealed butter and salt. Nope, no thanks.

uQdtUV4IPLq4O8m7zhw9cw.text: A very nice dining room with spectacular river views. Service woefully inadequate. Our server was nice enough but impossible to communicate with her. Asked if the chicken was on the bone and she had no idea what bone meant. She did however know how to try to sell up. Food OK but overpriced for the quality of the entire experience. Fish was nicely cooked and good presentation. Kitchen deserves a better front of house staff.

_0J7HvFC0aNVsAfXFu_8kg.text: A visit at The Globe is an experience that simply cannot be missed.Originally built for the performance of Shakespeare stage plays, the theatre building itself is worth admiring. It is beautifully decorated and made out to look like an original theatre from centuries past.The best time to visit The Globe is during the summer, when the performances take place on the stage and under the open sky. Going to see a show such as this really is a unique experience that gives you just an inkling of how theatre was in the past.It is interesting to visit The Globe, even if you do not go there to watch a performance, as there are brilliant guides to show you around at the theatre and tell you about its use and its most remarkable history.Plays are usually held during the day. . You can also go on a tour of the backstage area and the theatre of course.

dbL95q4agwJsxADc_bBaew.text: I watched the Much Ado About Nothing play and I am still fascinated about how wonderful it was! The actors are skilled (I don't know how much they actually are, but they know what they are doing), the stage is a place where time does not exist and the whole place just lets you forget about everything but the play you seeI recommend it to everybody who is interested in Shakespeare or at least in good theatre! Oh, and the rain is nothing that will ruin your evening! Just buy a ticket for the lodge and you'll be fine or enjoy the stances! As long as you don't mind wet shoes And by the way, you're in England. But really, it's worth it. The adjacency to the stage is brilliant.It's next to Millenium bridge, so you can take a nice walk across the Thames River while you wait!So: I can just recommend the whole location.

0W7tXdQvWcXZKlF33Cjtvw.text: I've been to the Globe many times - it helps to have a mother who is an English teacher and very keen on theatre - and hope to go back again many times. Visiting whilst still at secondary school, I've been lucky enough to stand on the stage myself, which is a remarkable experience. Since then, I've been to see a few production, with a trip to As You Like It already lined up for this summer. Maybe it's in my mind, but Shakespeare always seems easier to understand when it's performed here! The building is amazing, the recreation of the Elizabethan stalls and stage as near to perfect as I can imagine. The atmosphere during any performance, regardless of the time of day or the weather (I've been there in the cold, in the sun and the rain) is always remarkable. And the museum underneath isn't half bad either!

cue-PFmmXyCUCXXJHvny4g.text: Brilliant experience! Being a groundling is worth doing once, but don't choose a long play and do bring a cushion for the interval! Don't buy restricted view seating, it's just frustrating and not worth it! Book early! Also: cracking gift shop.

Tc1cr6ZdLaD775uukJ5u5g.text: If you like literature, or have studied, or even if you know the name William Shakespeare, then the Globe Theatre is definitely worth a visit.One of my favourite places in London, the replica theatre (the original burnt down and was further back from the Thames) takes you back to a time when theatre was the main form of entertainment.The tour around the Globe itself is interesting and full of facts - just make sure you ask all the questions you want as you will find the tour guide will then open up and let you deeper into Shakespeare's world!Best to sign-up to the Globe website so they can let you know when their summer theatre season begins. I am going to see King Lear in June and I absolutely cannot wait!

Ouh8kBYNyLFYqAWoyh5A-w.text: Located on the south bank, overlooking the magnificent St Paul's cathedral, The Swan is many things for many people  for some, it is a tony spot for a cheeky liquid lunch. For others, it's a place to impress a first date. For others, it's a unique family location. The best part about the Swan? It manages to rise to the occasion, no matter what the occasion. The Sunday late brunch/lunch is a leisurely affair  enjoy a lovely eggs florentine with an amazing Bacardi, cordial, and champagne minx called The Theatre. The Swan also features pre theatre packages and a lovely men's/women's high tea for the weekday crowd. But for me, a Sunday lunch at the Swan is the best of England. Enjoy.

XSfkYksMgdA_yiBEdXliSA.text: I came in for a late lunch with low expectations but was so pleasantly surprised by the delicious food. We had the pork belly, goat cheese, chips with garlic mayonnaise... It was all well prepared, well seasoned, and just so yummy!

g-WMC96ovOoCmDfkcdQbiA.text: What an amazing place to visit. Excellent location right near the restaurants on the waterfront. Even if you are not a massive Shakespeare fan you have to experience the atmosphere and performances in this building. It is definitely something that you will remember.

L_cMTZQuQgtLcqSrx8lmRw.text: Nothing quite prepares you for the absolute splendour of this unique landmark!It is like being transported back in time. I went to see Richard III performed this evening and wow what an experience a wonderful performance and an utterly breathtaking experience. Even the break in-between you can enjoy some excellent food and wine (even the burgers are good!) However be prepared the seats are not comfortable so hire a cushion and a backrest-its worth it!You can get cheap standing tickets but i wouldnt advise it-3 hours is a long time to stand especially if its raining, cold etc or exceptionally hot. Plus the view from above makes for a better experience. Don't miss it!

A6mHRmFE3kuMG2T8Zq2Vkg.text: We went down recently for an open day for Shakespeare's 300th birthday, bless 'im. I had visited here previously for a corporate event but this was a chance to have a better look around. The Bard was looking pretty good for his age - Firstly we took a look through the museum. It's a bit dated and naff for a museum. Personally I love all the info detailing the rebuilding of the Globe, the info on London at the time etc, but I think the main space there could be a little bit better in its lighting and ease of access. It's a little bit like being led around a rat run. After we'd seen the museum we went upstairs to view the theatre itself. Much better!We sat in the sun and watched some of the free performances of music and recitals by members of the unsuspecting public. For corporates there is a amll auditorium and various small meeting and dining rooms that can be hired. My favourite is the Swan at the Globe restuarant and the room abouve it that both look over the Thames with views up and down the river. Don't know if I would really pay to see the museum, but definitely worth a performance - especially at the £5.00 standing deals they do all summer.
